node.title: We're very poor at judging risks — sometimes, we need to see them to understand them
node.alt: A nurse pulls up a syringe of COVID-19 vaccine.
node.description: Numerical truths count for little when it comes to our perceptions of things like diseases and vaccines — we're more affected by the views of our peers.
node.content:
["It's easy to get lost in numbers.\u00a0Let me throw a bunch at you.", "About 190,000 Australians have been infected with COVID-19. Its death rate\u00a0this year\u00a0is 0.4 per cent.\u00a0The odds of getting a dangerous blood\u00a0clot from the AstraZeneca vaccine are about 50,000 to one.", "The problem with very big and very small numbers like these\u00a0is that human brains just aren't wired to comprehend them.", "Psychologists have studied this limitation for decades. Sometimes,\u00a0we need to see numbers to understand them.", "This chart\u00a0depicts what happened to 1,000 Australians who caught COVID-19 this year (excluding children under 12). It represents typical infection outcomes, according to\u00a0federal Health Department data.", "The blue chart below shows 1,000 vaccination outcomes, using Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation data.", "It's all blue because 1,000 is far too small a sample to represent the likelihood of even a single person experiencing, for example, mild heart pain following a Pfizer dose.", "That symptom might (but probably wouldn't) indicate myocarditis, a temporary reaction that has not killed anyone in Australia.", "We'd need more than 2,000 of these blue charts, all combined, to have enough space to accurately convey the risk\u00a0of dying from a vaccine: a single black mark lost in a sea of more than 2 million other dots.", "Can you see it? Probably not. After all, popping an aspirin is significantly more likely to kill you than a COVID-19 vaccine.", "Perhaps a\u00a0simpler way to understand COVID-19 risks is to look at 1,000 New South Wales residents at the height of the Delta outbreak in September.", "The charts below depict\u00a0500 vaccinated and 500 unvaccinated people (excluding children) and whether they became infected, based on NSW Health epidemiological\u00a0reports.", "Yes, vaccinated people still get the disease\u00a0but, as can be seen here, they're both less likely to\u00a0and, if they do, face a smaller risk of severe illness.", "
Perception is subjective
", "Numerical truths count for little when it comes to our\u00a0perceptions, University of New South Wales academics\u00a0say.", "COVID-19 vaccines, for example, are safer than common drugs like aspirin and ibuprofen, but the injections provoke much deeper fears than painkillers.", "Many cues in our surroundings distort how we understand risks.", "Here's one: Australia's official terrorism threat level today is \"probable\" \u2014 a very\u00a0odd description for\u00a0a highly improbable risk\u00a0for Australians, based on the experience of recent decades.", "", "
Americans fear dying from terrorism, a tiny risk compared with gun violence.(AP: Michael Noble Jr)
", "Similarly, a 2016 survey found\u00a0more Americans were afraid of terrorism\u00a0than of gun violence, even though the latter was 3,210 times more likely to kill them.", "Diana Cardenas, a psychologist\u00a0at the Australian National University, has been researching Australians' perceptions of COVID-19 and vaccines.", "Early in the pandemic, she led a study on who was likely to accept or be wary of vaccines.", "She said a person's social group\u00a0was usually the most important influence on their perceptions, regardless of whether that was rational.", "", "
Research psychologist Diana Cardenas says our perceptions are affected by our peers' views.(Supplied)
", "For example, Australians were more likely to say they would trust a vaccine developed by Australian scientists than by French scientists.", "\"We fundamentally trust 'our group' more than people who are from other groups,\" she said.", "Dr Cardenas also found the extent to which Australians had faith in government was a strong predictor of whether they would trust a vaccine \u2014 a finding echoed in research across the world.", "\"It's not whether I'm left-oriented [politically] or right-oriented, it's whether I trust the government as an institution that matters,\" she said.", "This made it especially difficult for health officials to reach those who would benefit most from information about COVID-19.", "The challenge for governments was to try to inform people who were influential in vaccine-hesitant communities, so they could\u00a0convince others \u2014 an approach that required patience.", "\"It's just so hard to change people's minds,\" Dr Cardenas said."]
